status_message: Researchers can now measure the urine people leave in swimming pools and hot tubs, reports Science News for Students.
link_name: Scientists know that you pee in the pool

status_message: A hard look at experimental setups may start to explain dueling predictions on whether ocean acidification will boost, or choke, vital marine nitrogen fixers.
link_name: Ocean acidification may hamper food web's nitrogen-fixing heroes

status_message: Particles with mind-bending quantum properties still follow a standard gravitational rule, at least as far as scientists can tell.
link_name: Key Einstein principle survives quantum test

status_message: Cassini has beamed back stunning images from the spacecraft's daring dive between Saturn and its rings.
link_name: Cassini's ring dive offers first close-up of Saturn's cloud tops

status_message: Researchers have been trying for 60 years to make an artificial womb or artificial placenta to help premature babies.
link_name: Faux womb keeps preemie lambs alive

status_message: Data suggest that the heliosphere, the bubble of particles surrounding the solar system, is spherical, not comet-shaped.
link_name: No long, twisted tail trails the solar system

status_message: Here are five things we learned from a massive genetics study of more than 1,300 dogs representing 161 breeds.
link_name: Dog DNA study maps breeds across the world

status_message: The New World was a surprisingly old destination for humans or our evolutionary relatives, a new study suggests.
link_name: First settlers reached Americas 130,000 years ago, study claims

status_message: Tonight Cassini takes its first pass through the 2,400-kilometer-wide gap between Saturn and its rings.
link_name: In 'grand finale,' Cassini spacecraft sets off on collision course with Saturn

status_message: A fluid-filled bag that mimics the womb kept premature lambs alive and developing normally for four weeks.
link_name: Faux womb keeps preemie lambs alive

status_message: Tonight, a new TV series about Albert Einstein premieres on National Geographic, but be prepared for an emphasis on drama, sex and love stories, not science.
link_name: The drama of Albert Einstein's life unfolds in the new series Genius

status_message: Studying the way venom molecules from diverse fishes inflict pain might help researchers understand how nerve cells sense pain and lead to novel ways to dull the sensation.
link_name: Venomous fish have evolved many ways to inflict pain

status_message: For one thing, we learned that Thomas Jefferson was a real stickler about typos in scientific texts.

status_message: A potential sign of dark matter is looking less convincing in the wake of a new analysis.

status_message: Ötzi the Tyrolean Iceman died of exposure to cold temperatures in the Italian Alps, a new study concludes.
link_name: Ötzi the Iceman froze to death

status_message: Some babies who go on to receive autism diagnoses may have more cerebrospinal fluid on part of their brain that babies who do not get diagnosed with autism.
link_name: Scientists seek early signs of autism

status_message: A 2013 circumpolar expedition discovered hundreds of tons of plastic debris, from fishing lines to plastic films, in the Arctic Ocean.
link_name: The Arctic is a final garbage dump for ocean plastic

status_message: Identifying the cause of the hydroxyl changes could help climate scientists better predict how methane levels will behave in the future.

status_message: Cassini is boldly going where no spacecraft has gone before — between Saturn and its rings.
link_name: In 'grand finale,' Cassini spacecraft sets off on collision course with Saturn

status_message: Two complementary effects tag team to untie a runner's shoelace in this video: impact and inertia. Read more: http://ow.ly/CpdL30b4qBq
link_name: How do shoelaces come untied? | Science News

status_message: Some scientists have expressed concern that marching coats science in a partisan sheen; others say that cat is long out of the bag.
link_name: March for Science will take scientists' activism to a new level

status_message: "We know very little about the early evolutionary history of dinosaurs and their closest relatives, but discoveries like Teleocrater are helping change that picture."
link_name: Early dinosaur relative sported odd mix of bird, crocodile-like traits

status_message: Tune in to hear what speakers at the March for Science in D.C. have to say starting around 10am eastern time.
link_name: Watch the March for Science in Washington, D.C.

status_message: Scientists and philosophers team up to help robots make good choices, reports Science News for Students.
link_name: Teaching robots right from wrong

status_message: Today certainly isn't the first time scientists have taken to the streets. Here's our coverage of a series of rallies in support of research freedom and against Nazism and pseudoscience in 1939. #MarchforScience
link_name: Science News 1939: Defense of Democracy Urged at Meeting of Scientists

status_message: A shortage of neutrinos from nuclear reactors is probably due to a miscalculation, not a new type of neutrino.

status_message: Cassini is bravely going where no spacecraft has gone before — between Saturn and its rings.
link_name: In 'grand finale,' Cassini spacecraft sets off on collision course with Saturn

status_message: Changes in the concentration of a highly reactive compound in the atmosphere called hydroxyl may be to blame for a rise in global methane levels since 2007, new research suggests.
link_name: Plot twist in methane mystery blames chemistry, not emissions, for recent rise

status_message: Science News 1967: "Continental drift, a theory often considered amusing but rarely important, seems about to become the focus of a revolution in geology."
link_name: 50 years ago, continental drift began to gain acceptance

status_message: Scientists have been politically engaged in the past, but historians are calling the upcoming march unprecedented.
link_name: March for Science will take scientists' activism to a new level

status_message: Does the strategy of cocooning where people who will be in contact with a newborn all receive vaccinations to protect the vulnerable baby actually work?
link_name: Evidence is lacking that 'cocooning' prevents whooping cough in newborns

status_message: Plastic garbage from Europe and the U.S. East Coast is piling up in the Arctic Ocean.
link_name: The Arctic is a final garbage dump for ocean plastic

status_message: Could the next flu drug could come from frog mucus? 'Snot as crazy as it sounds.

status_message: Plasma taken from human umbilical cords can rejuvenate old mice's brains and improve their memories.

status_message: Penguins have been pooping on Ardley Island off the coast of the Antarctic Peninsula for a long, long time.
link_name: Volcanic eruptions nearly snuffed out Gentoo penguin colony, excremental evidence suggests

status_message: Clovis people fashioned stone weapons that slightly crumpled at the base rather than breaking at the tip when thrust into prey.
link_name: Shock-absorbing spear points kept early North Americans on the hunt

status_message: Saturn's main moon, Titan, has a "magic island," which might be made of streams of nitrogen bubbles.
link_name: Bubbles may put mysterious fizz in Titan's polar sea

status_message: More than half of the energy for the unexpectedly large tsunami that devastated Japan in 2011 originated from the horizontal movement of the seafloor.
link_name: More than one ocean motion determines tsunami size

status_message: Secrets of the humble proton could have physicists rethinking some standard notions about matter and the universe.
link_name: There's still a lot we don't know about the proton

status_message: With the ankle of a crocodile and the skull of a dinosaur, Teleocrater rhadinus changes the look of early dinosaur relatives.
link_name: Early dinosaur relative sported odd mix of bird, crocodile-like traits

status_message: A new 10-episode series, Genius, airing on the National Geographic Channel, focuses on the facets of Einstein's life where he was anything but a virtuoso.
link_name: The drama of Albert Einstein's life unfolds in the new series Genius

status_message: Eels can sense changes in Earth's magnetic field to find highways in a featureless expanse of ocean.

status_message: This isn't the end for sterile neutrinos — there are other hints that they exist.
link_name: New particle probably can't explain nuclear reactor neutrino mystery

status_message: "We are not saying Enceladus has life, but the discovery does move the moon higher on the list of potentially habitable places in the solar system."

status_message: "With this device, you can harvest the equivalent of a Coke can's worth of water in an hour."
link_name: New tech harvests drinking water from (relatively) dry air using only sunlight

status_message: Barring genetic tests for a handful of rare mutations, there are no blood draws, brain scans or other biological tests that can reveal whether a child has — or will get — autism.

status_message: Hospital admission rates for heart attacks declined 7.8 percent more in New York counties that restricted trans fats than in those counties that had not.
link_name: Rules restricting artificial trans fats are good for heart health

status_message: There's now hard evidence for the benefits of vaccinating women while pregnant instead of shortly after giving birth.
link_name: Vaccinating pregnant women protects newborns from whooping cough

status_message: Swirling winds in the Andes Mountains can carry gypsum crystals several kilometers before dumping them in large piles.
link_name: Whirlwinds of crystals called gravel devils spotted in Andes Mountains

status_message: Earthquake-powered shifts along the seafloor that push water forward, not just up, could help supersize tsunamis.
link_name: More than one ocean motion determines tsunami size

status_message: Why do shoelaces always come untied? The combined forces from legs swinging and feet pounding the pavement create a perfect lace-loosening storm.
link_name: Physics trips up efforts to keep shoelaces tied

status_message: A new device the size of a coffee mug can generate drinkable water from desert air using nothing but sunlight.

status_message: Hospital admission rates for heart attacks declined 7.8 percent more in New York counties that restricted trans fats than in those counties that had not.
link_name: Rules restricting artificial trans fats are good for heart health

status_message: Jupiter shares its orbit around the sun with a slew of asteroids, but this one goes against the flow.
link_name: Asteroid in Jupiter's orbit goes its own way

status_message: A Tdap vaccine during pregnancy led to fewer newborns getting whooping cough in the two months after birth, a large study found.
link_name: Vaccinating pregnant women protects newborns from whooping cough

status_message: Geochemical evidence of Gentoo penguin poop helped researchers pinpoint volcanoes as an ancient threat to one of today's most successful Antarctic penguin colonies.
link_name: Volcanic eruptions nearly snuffed out Gentoo penguin colony

status_message: Blame physics — not kindergarten-level clumsiness — for perpetually untied shoelaces, researchers at UC Berkeley report.
link_name: Physics trips up efforts to keep shoelaces tied

status_message: The Great Barrier Reef is on the decline, and the window to save it is closing.
link_name: The Great Barrier Reef is experiencing a major coral bleaching event right now

status_message: Researchers in China and Texas have used CRISPR/Cas9 to repair disease-causing mutations in viable human embryos.
link_name: Gene editing of human embryos yields early results

status_message: Solar wind has expelled two-thirds of the Martian atmosphere's argon and a majority of its carbon dioxide into space.
link_name: Extreme gas loss dried out Mars, MAVEN data suggest

status_message: The oldest known specimens of bedbug relatives have been unearthed in an Oregon cave system where ancient humans once lived.
link_name: Bedbugs bugged prehistoric humans, too

status_message: Fluorescent frogs don't have bedroom black lights, but their glow may still be about the night moves.
link_name: First fluorescent frogs might see each others' glow

status_message: There is a less sequins-and-glitter side to CRISPR that's just as alluring to anyone thirsty to understand the natural world.

status_message: Scientists set out calf carcasses for a study of scavengers. One went missing. Why? A badger buried it.

status_message: This week, the Event Horizon Telescope began taking data. Here's what spotting a black hole's event horizon could tell us.
link_name: The mysterious boundary

status_message: Early exposure to language patterns the brain in ways that may not be revealed for decades.
link_name: Language heard, but never spoken, by young babies bestows a hidden benefit

status_message: The data offer evidence for a population of inactive galaxies early in the universe, which are extremely difficult to observe.

status_message: Nearly 12 percent of childhood cancer survivors carry mutations that increase the risk of a subsequent cancer.

status_message: Biologists are seeing signs that animals and plants are adapting to survive in cities. Their genes are changing, Science News for Students reports.
link_name: Cities drive animals and plants to evolve

status_message: For a new exhibit at The Field Museum, curators brought out about 5,600 additional items — from preserved deep-sea creatures and fossilized brains to meteorites — to show the diversity of the museum's hidden collections.
link_name: 'Specimens' goes behind the scenes of Chicago's Field Museum

status_message: An interaction of young stars in Orion Molecular Core 1 ripped apart a stellar nursery, sending stars, gas and dust shooting into space.
link_name: Squabbles in star nurseries result in celestial fireworks

status_message: A common virus may turn the immune system against gluten, leading to the development of celiac disease.

status_message: Straying from prescribed genetic instructions may have increased thinking prowess for octopuses, squid and cuttlefish — but that comes at a cost.

status_message: A hefty galaxy in the early universe bulked up quickly but then suddenly stopped making stars.
link_name: Massive red, dead galaxy spotted in young universe

status_message: CRISPR may be the dazzling star of the biotech world, but bacteria and archaea armed with CRISPR systems have been at war with viruses for eons.
link_name: CRISPR had a life before it became a gene-editing tool

status_message: Starting today, scientists will attempt to zoom in on a never-before-imaged realm: a black hole's event horizon.
link_name: Event Horizon Telescope to try to capture images of elusive black hole edge

status_message: Immune cells engineered to hunt and destroy cancer cells may help some people with one type of leukemia live much longer.

status_message: In response to nuclear power plant shutdowns in the 1980s, some coal plants ramped up power production — and air pollution. Babies born near one such plant after the boost had lower birth weights, an indicator of poorer health.
link_name: When coal replaces a cleaner energy source, health is on the line

status_message: The coarse skull bones of a newly identified tyrannosaur hint that it had sensory organs in its face.

status_message: A previous exposure to dengue or West Nile can make a Zika virus infection worse, experiments in cells and mice suggest.

status_message: A new exhibit at Chicago's Field Museum puts seldom-seen collections on display to spotlight their role in science.
link_name: 'Specimens' goes behind the scenes of Chicago's Field Museum

status_message: Asteroid 2015 BZ509 is the first object found that orbits in the same region as a planet but travels backward.
link_name: Asteroid in Jupiter's orbit goes its own way

status_message: Girls and boys with ADHD behave differently. It turns out that parts of their brains look different, too.
link_name: More brain differences seen between girls, boys with ADHD

status_message: Human germline editing wasn't realistic until CRISPR/Cas9 and other new gene editors came along. "We've now gotten to the point where it's possible to imagine a day when it would be safe enough" to be feasible, says bioethicist R. Alta Charo.
link_name: Gene editing of human embryos yields early results

status_message: A female glass frog guards her eggs despite annoying finger prods from scientists. This species provides the only prolonged maternal care yet found among glass frogs, but even short-term moms stayed on duty when researchers poked at them. Read more: http://ow.ly/Tf7o30atKzY
link_name: Glass frog mom guards her brood

status_message: In a feat of quantum one-upmanship, two teams of scientists have staked new claims of linking whopping numbers of atoms at the quantum level.

status_message: A review of eight studies attempts to clarify whether kids who drink 100 percent fruit juice every day are at greater risk of gaining weight.

status_message: The results could help explain the details of how tectonic plates glide on top of Earth's mantle.

status_message: Badgers are known to squirrel away scavenged food. Camera trap footage shows just how dedicated they can be.

status_message: Maternal care wouldn't be news among mammals or birds, but frogs are a different story.
link_name: For glass frogs, moms matter after all

status_message: In a spaceflight first, the aerospace company SpaceX has successfully launched and landed a previously used rocket.

status_message: Solar wind stripped away two-thirds of the argon and a majority of the carbon dioxide in Mars' atmosphere.

status_message: This newly identified dinosaur may have had highly sensitive organs in its face that could detect touch and temperature.

status_message: Researchers have successfully edited disease-causing mutations out of viable human embryos using the gene-editing tool known as CRISPR/Cas9.

status_message: Al Gore released a trailer this week for the upcoming sequel to "An Inconvenient Truth." Last spring we checked in on some of the forecasts and predictions made in the 2006 documentary.

status_message: A new study suggests that accidental mistakes are the source of 66 percent of mutations in cancer cells across the board.

status_message: Bug sprays with DEET or oil of lemon eucalyptus deter mosquitoes better than repellent bracelets or citronella candles.

status_message: A black hole weighing more than a billion suns appears to have gotten the boot toward the outer edges of its galaxy.

status_message: It's not the size of a snake's muscles that matter, but how it uses them.

status_message: Remnants of a royal palace in southern Mexico come from what must have been one of the Americas' earliest large, centralized governments.

status_message: Huns and farmers living around the Roman Empire's eastern border borrowed traded tips during the fifth century.

status_message: In a feat of quantum one-upmanship, two teams of scientists have staked new claims of linking whopping numbers of atoms at the quantum level.

status_message: "The cell surface is basically coated with sugars," says Carolyn Bertozzi, a chemist at Stanford University. "They're what viruses, bacteria and other cells see first when they touch down on a target cell."
link_name: Cancer cells cast a sweet spell on the immune system

status_message: Droplets of chemicals replicate, new simulations indicate. That process repeats to create new generations of droplets in a process that mimics reproduction — and could reveal the origins of life.
link_name: Life on Earth may have begun as dividing droplets

status_message: "The Zoo," the tale of the founding of the London Zoo, lays out a grand saga of human ambition and audacity. But it's the animals' stories that catch hold of readers and don't let go.
link_name: Shocking stories tell tale of London Zoo's founding

status_message: Pluto is a planet — always has been, always will be, says planetary scientist Will Grundy.

status_message: These new findings challenge the common wisdom that cancer is the product of heredity and the environment.
link_name: Random mutations play large role in cancer, study finds

status_message: Brain size (such as it is) in a female guppy turns out to affect her taste in males.
link_name: Female guppies with bigger brains pick more attractive guys

status_message: How much do you think the government spends on science? Chances are, you're way off, a new study shows.
link_name: Most Americans like science — and are willing to pay for it

status_message: From Science News for Students: Some scientists want to talk to aliens. But what if ET isn't friendly?

status_message: Huns and Romans weren't quite countrymen but lent each other some food, archaeological finds suggest.
link_name: Ancient Romans may have been cozier with Huns than they let on

status_message: In this data storage device, each bit is encoded using the magnetic field of a single atom.
link_name: Single-atom magnets store bits of data

status_message: A magnitude 7.8 earthquake that hit New Zealand last year jumped between two faults thought to be too far apart for a quake to cross.

status_message: Researchers have identified new enemies in the war on cancer: ones that are already inside cells and that no one can avoid.

status_message: LSD briefly got tagged as a gene breaker a half century ago before getting a reprieve.

status_message: When choosing more attractive guys, girl guppies with larger brains have an advantage over their smaller-brained counterparts.
link_name: Female guppies with bigger brains pick more attractive guys

status_message: Our April 1 issue is now online! Read about digital tech on the brain, cancer's sweet spell, elephant sleep stats, ancient stardust spotted, a hydrothermal cradle of life, nutrition in a changing climate and more: http://ow.ly/jpjB30a9J9T

status_message: In a primordial soup on ancient Earth, droplets of chemicals may have paved the way for the first cells.

status_message: At least one of comet 67P/Churyumov-Gerasimenko's dusty outbursts was the result of a landslide.

status_message: Superfluid helium follows an unusual rule known from black holes — one with mysterious significance for physics.

status_message: It's not the size of a snake's muscles that matter, but how it uses them.

status_message: Isobel Charman's latest book, The Zoo, chronicles the early days of the Gardens of the Zoological Society of London, known today as the London Zoo.

status_message: Madagascar's Geckolepis megalepis strips down and slips away, looking more like slimy pink Silly Putty than a rugged lizard.

status_message: If confirmed, these results could lead astronomers to reconsider the role dark matter played in early galaxy evolution and might also offer clues to how nearby elliptical galaxies evolved.

status_message: While many nature writers might offer philosophical musings on waterways, "Where the River Flows" author Sean Fleming has physics on his side.

status_message: Blood infections in young children fell after the introduction of the vaccine PCV7 in 2000, and fell even more after PCV13 came into use in 2010.

status_message: Small studies are turning up hints that our devices may change how we remember, how we navigate and how we create happiness — or not.

status_message: Thanks to the messiness of reality, a forger with access to sophisticated equipment could skirt that quantum security.

status_message: Climate change could shrink the mineral and protein content of wheat, rice and other staple crops.

status_message: Parasites can drive their hosts to do weird, dumb things. But in this case, parasites themselves get played.
link_name: How one enslaving wasp eats through another

status_message: "If you ask five geologists the simple question of when did plate tectonics start, you'll have answers from 4.3 billion years ago to 1 billion years ago."

status_message: Science News for Students talks to three scientists exploring all-natural ways to make light — and their promise for new technologies.
link_name: Cool Jobs: A world aglow

status_message: King snakes coil around mice like a spring, squeezing tight enough to stop a rodent's heart.

status_message: Ravioli? Walnut? Empanada? You decide what Saturn's moon Pan looks like in the latest shots from Cassini.

status_message: Huge cuts could be in store for federal science spending if President Donald Trump's vision for fiscal year 2018 becomes reality.

status_message: A frictionless form of helium appears to follow the same counterintuitive 'area law' as black holes.

status_message: Some bedbugs are better climbers than others, and the bloodsuckers' climbing prowess has implications for traps.

status_message: Very distant galaxies have surprisingly little dark matter, the invisible stuff thought to make up the bulk of matter in the universe.

status_message: It's Pi Day! Read up on how mathematicians tackled the seeming randomness of pi's digits.

status_message: In 1936, great relativist Albert Einstein received a patent on a "light intensity self-adjusting camera." Here's our story from back in the day and follow-up.

status_message: Happy #PiDay! How do you transform a circle into a square? The solution hinges on the properties of the number pi.
link_name: Squaring Circles

status_message: Born March 14, 1879, Albert Einstein inspired a new vision of the entire fabric of the cosmos with his general theory of relativity.

status_message: Boosting these prodigious mnemonic skills came with overhauls in brain activity, resulting in brains that behaved more like those of experts who win World Memory Championships competitions.

status_message: This drone could one day fill in for bees, picking up pollen from one flower and depositing it on another.

status_message: A dinner plate piled high with food from plants might not deliver the same nutrition toward the end of this century as it does today.

status_message: Scientists have created an ultrasecure form of money using quantum mechanics — and immediately demonstrated a potential security loophole.

status_message: This week, Cassini captured the closest images ever taken of Pan, a small moon that orbits amid Saturn's rings.

status_message: Crime prediction software programs can lead to policing that unfairly targets minorities and those living in poorer neighborhoods.

status_message: A distant, young galaxy is filled with dust probably produced by the first supernova explosions in the universe.

status_message: Choice architects like to prod us to save for retirement and eat healthier, but nudging doesn't always end well.

status_message: With five more synthetic chromosomes built, scientists are closer to creating a synthetic genome for Saccharomyces cerevisiae yeast.

status_message: Central Asian herders routinely migrated from highland pastures in summer to lowland areas in winter along routes that that became a key part of the silk road.

status_message: In The Death and Life of the Great Lakes, journalist Dan Egan describes how the lakes' natural history gave way to an unnatural one.

status_message: Much of what we learn about how VR affects people will show up first in living rooms and on Twitter rather than in scientific labs and journals.

status_message: Science isn't the only hurdle in developing vaccines for mosquito-borne diseases. The latest yellow fever outbreak in Brazil shows that stockpiles are another roadblock: http://ow.ly/IwC9309NI6M.

status_message: Scientists study how animals hibernate and how doing so might benefit people, reports Science News for Students.

status_message: Training with an ancient mnemonic technique boosts a person's memory and changes their brain, a new study suggests.
link_name: Brain training turns recall rookies into memory masters

status_message: Corn genetically engineered to make ninjalike molecules can launch an attack on invading fungi, stopping the production of carcinogenic toxins.

status_message: Inspired by a popular line of psychological research and introduced in a best-selling book a decade ago, nudges are currently on a roll.
link_name: Nudging people to make good choices can backfire

status_message: Like people, mice experience sudden itches after seeing other mice scratch — a boon for studying the neuroscience of contagious behaviors.
link_name: Scratching is catching in mice

status_message: The Tully monster's strange features have made it difficult to classify, but new research suggests that it wasn't a vertebrate.
link_name: Identity of 'Tully monster' still a mystery
